content.transcript:
There are four types of contamination hazard: microbiological, physical, chemical and allergenic.

Click on the graphics to learn more about each type of contamination hazard.

Microbiological hazards include micro-organisms like bacteria, viruses, moulds, yeasts and parasites.

Bacterial contamination usually occurs within food premises because of ignorance, lack of space, poor design or due to people taking short cuts

Viral contamination may involve an infected person, polluted irrigation water used on salads or oysters grown in sewage-contaminated water.

Moulds and yeasts are primarily responsible for spoilage.

Physical hazards include foreign bodies which are dangerous, for example, glass, nails and stones.

They may cause cuts, broken teeth, choking and burning in the case of food which is too hot.

Physical hazards may be brought into food premises with the raw materials or could be introduced during storage, preparation, service or display.

Sources include:
  • Raw ingredients for example stones and bones;
  • Buildings and equipment can introduce wood and flaking paint/rust;
  • Notice boards for example drawing pins; packaging such as cardboard and staples;
  • Maintenance operatives may introduce screws and wire;
  • Food handlers can contaminate food with jewellery;
  • First aid dressings and hair;
  • Cleaning materials for example bristles or pieces of cloths;
  • Pests can introduce bodies and droppings;
  • Finally sabotage for example needles and razor blades.

Deliveries of foods may be contaminated with chemicals such as pesticides, weed killers and dioxins.

Cleaning chemicals and chemicals used for pest control may also contaminate food, for example, if sprayed near unprotected food.

If food is stored in old chemical containers, it may also become contaminated. Using packaging, which is not food grade can also contaminate food.

Allergens are substances, usually protein, which cause the bodies immune system to respond.

In severe cases this may result in anaphylactic shock and even death.

Foods commonly containing allergens include:
  • Peanuts and other nuts;
  • Sesame seeds;
  • Milk including lactose;
  • Eggs;
  • Fish and shellfish;
  • Soya;
  • Mustard;
  • Cereals containing gluten;
  • Celery/celeriac; and
  • Products containing any of the above.
